editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Rector and Fellows of Exeter College.

msDesc.head: Stephen Langton; Anselm; etc.; England, s. xiiiin

msItem.title: Contents list
msItem.note: The date is s. xiiiin. Item 12 below is added in a hand of s. xv.

msItem.title: ‘De xii prophetis hee lecciones ad missas sunt excerpte.’
msItem.note: Nine feasts in a hand of s. xii/xiii, and a tenth added, s. xv.

msItem.author: Stephen Langton
msItem.title: In librum Thobie
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus magistri Stephani Cantuariensis archiepiscopi in expositionem libri Thobie.
msItem.incipit: In genesi legimus. Fiant luminaria in firmamento celi ... In quarum utraque peritus fuit.
Thobias ex tribu et ciuitate Neptalim etc. Ecce in principio commendat personam
msItem.explicit: Cetera usque ad finem libri patent.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit Expositio magistri Stephani Cantuariensis Archiepiscopi. In libro Thobie.
msItem.note: Stegmüller, Bibl., 7761; Glorieux, Théologie, 104j6; Lacombe and Smalley, 67, 178, 179. On Langton see Sharpe, Latin Writers.

msItem.author: Stephen Langton
msItem.title: In librum Judith
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus magistri Stephani Cantuariensis archiepiscopi in expositionem libri Iudith.
msItem.incipit: In ecclesiastico legitur. Lucerna splendens super candelabrum aureum
msItem.explicit: Vsque in presentem diem id est dum durat presens seculum.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit expositio magistri .S. Cantuariensis Archiepiscopi. In libro Iudith.
msItem.note: Stegmüller, Bibl., 7762; Glorieux, Théologie, 104j7; Lacombe and Smalley, 67, 178.

msItem.author: Stephen Langton
msItem.title: In librum Hester
msItem.rubric: Incipit eiusdem .S. prologus in exposicionem libri Hester.
msItem.incipit: In prouerbiis legitur. Mulier graciosa inueniet gloriam
Librum Hester uariis translatoribus constat esse
[fol. 17v] Duplex enim fuit ordo sentenciarum. In diebus assueri regis
msItem.explicit: Verbum notabile contra illos qui temere iudicant.
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt Notule magistri Stephani Cantuariensis archiepiscopi. in libro Hester.
msItem.note: Stegmüller, Bibl., 7763; Glorieux, Théologie, 104j8; Lacombe and Smalley, 67, 165, 178.

msItem.author: Stephen Langton
msItem.title: In libros xii prophetum minorum
msItem.note: (Series A)
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus magistri Stephani Cantuariensis in prophetas duodecim.
msItem.incipit: Ossa duodecim prophetarum pullulant de loco suo. nam corroborauerunt Iacob
Verbum domini quod factum est ad Osee filium Beeri in diebus Ozie
[fol. 79r] et maiores stillabunt
msItem.note: Stegmüller, Bibl., 7843–54. For other manuscripts see Lacombe and Smalley, 67, 145–7. Because of the excision of a leaf, our text has a gap between fols. 77v/78r in the commentary on Amos, iii. 9.

msItem.title: Pamphilus de amore
msItem.note: lines 12, 21–2
msItem.incipit: Solet ars dominum sepe iuuare suum. ¶ Conditus ignis. acrior effusus parcior esse solet
msItem.note: ed. F. G. Becker, Pamphilus: Prolegomena zum Pamphilus (de amore) und kritische Textausgabe, Beihefte zum “Mittellateinisches Jahrbuch”, 9 (Ratingen, Düsseldorf, 1972). M. Manitius, Geschichte der lateinischen Literatur des Mittelalters, iii (1931), 1032–4.

msItem.author: Vitalis Blesensis
msItem.title: Geta
msItem.incipit: ¶ Quemlibet in modicus aligat eris amor multa licet sapias re sine nullus eris. ¶ Fessis post onera fit mage grata quies. ¶ Improuisa magis uulnera sepe nocent.
msItem.note: ed. A. Paeske, Der “Geta” des Vitalis von Blois: kritische Ausgabe, Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlangung des Doktorgrades ... der Universität Köln (Cologne, 1976). Manitius, ibid., 1016–18; WIC 7272 etc.

msItem.incipit: Beatissimus martyr Thomas Cantuariensis archiepiscopus ob uanas que nagas cordis cogitationes reprimendas
msItem.explicit: Hunc inquam habebat. ibidem ab oracione ad lectionem se excipiens.
msItem.note: Part of the chapter ‘Qualis [Thomas Cantuariensis] fuerit in officio altaris’ from Herbert of Bosham’s Life of Becket, ed. J. C. Robinson, Materials for the History of Thomas Becket, iii (RS 67: London, 1877), 210/23–211/2; and as part of the Quadrilogus, ed. ibid., iv (1879), 286/33–287/9). In the margin, in the hand of John Grandisson, bp. of Exeter, d. 1369, is the title “Qualiter beatus Thomas martyr inter missarum solempnia se habebat’.

msItem.author: Anselmus
msItem.title: Orationes
msItem.incipit: Orationes siue meditationes que subscripte sunt
Omnipotens deus et misericor pater
msItem.explicit: semper exaudias saluator mundi. qui cum patre et spiritu sancto uiuis que regnas deus per omnia secula seculorum etc.
msItem.note: as ed. by F. S. Schmitt, Sancti Anselmi opera omnia, iii (Edinburgh, 1946), 5–75. On no. 7 see A. Wilmart, RTAM 2 (1930), 189–204 (this manuscript at 202). In the margin of fol. 165v, in Grandisson’s hand, is the title ‘Oraciones cum meditacionibus beati Anselmi. Prologus.’ On Anselm see Sharpe, Latin Writers.

msItem.author: Anselmus
msItem.title: Meditatio 3
msItem.incipit: Anima christiana anima de graui morte resuscitata
msItem.explicit: Occupet me totum et possideat me totum. quia tu es cum patre et spiritu sancto deus solus benedictus in secula seculorum. Amen.
msItem.note: ed. Schmitt (as above), 84–91.

msItem.author: Anselmus (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: Sancte ac beate angele dei cui me diuina bonitas ex quo per baptismatis sacramentum in filium adoptauit
msItem.explicit: merear ipso prestante cui cum patre et spiritu sancto una est diuinitas equalis gloria coeterna maiestas. Amen.
msItem.note: ed. A. Wilmart, ‘Prières à l’ange gardien’, Auteurs spirituels et textes dévots du moyen âge (Paris, 1932, repr. 1971), 537–58, at 544–51. Our manuscript is no. 6 in his list of seven manuscripts, all now in England.

msItem.author: Claudianus
msItem.title: In Rufinum
msItem.incipit: Res hominum multa caligine volui aspicio. Aeroque diu florere nocentis
msItem.note: ed. J. B. Hall (Leipzig, 1985) beginning with l. 12, and followed by 52 further lines of manuscript.

msItem.author: Alexander of Ashby (attrib.)
msItem.title: Argumenta bibliorum
msItem.note: without the prologue

rubric.add: Vetus et novum testamentum breuiter versificatum

msItem.incipit: Ante dies omnes mundi fuit omnes in uno
msItem.explicit: Absque dolore quies et sine nocte dies.
msItem.note: Stegmüller, Bibl., 1114 (York Minster, MS XVI. Q. 14 item 8); WIC 1291 (this copy and BL, MS Royal 6 B. xi item 12). Bale, Index, 22, recorded another copy ‘ex musaeo Roberti Talboti’. For others see Sharpe, Latin Writers. The titles added above are in Grandisson’s hand.

msItem.incipit: Terra salutiferas habebas eademque nocentes
msItem.note: Ovid, 34 lines, beg. with De remedio amoris, 3.45.

msItem.incipit: Cum fueris felix multos uenerabis amicos
msItem.note: Ovid, 14 lines, ending with Tristia, 5.12, 38.

msItem.incipit: Accipe perlongas tibi qui deseruiat annos
msItem.note: Ovid, 22 lines, beg. with Amores, 1.3.5.

msItem.incipit: Non est in medico semper releuetur ut eger
msItem.note: Ovid, 74 lines, beg. with De ponto, 1.3.17.

msItem.incipit: Res est solliciti plena timores amor
msItem.note: Ovid, 22 lines, beg. with Heroides, 1.12.

msItem.incipit: Parua leues capiunt animos
msItem.note: Ovid, 64 lines, beg. with De arte amandi, 1.159
Ovid, 10 lines, beg. with Fasti, 1.211.

msItem.incipit: Furor ira que mentem precipitant
msItem.note: Virgil, 19 lines, beg. with Aeneid, 2. 316.

msItem.incipit: Stimulos dedit emula virtus
msItem.note: Lucan, 37 lines, beg. with De bello civile, 1.120

msItem.incipit: Ridentem dicere uerum quis uetat
msItem.note: Horace, 10 lines, beg. with Sermones, 1.1.24

msItem.incipit: Non possis oculo quantum contendere Lincheus
msItem.note: Horace, 82 lines, beg. with Epistola, 1. 1. 28

msItem.incipit: Mors equo pulsat pede pauperum tabernas
msItem.note: Horace, 50 lines, beg. with Carmina, 1. 4. 13

msItem.incipit: Vacuum ferit improba lingua palatum
msItem.note: Proverbia Alexandri, 278 lines, apparently the same text as WIC 11830, found in Cambrai, Bibl. mun., MS 977 (s. xiii), fol. 169v et seq., entitled ‘Exceptiones quedam prouerbiorum Alexandri’

msItem.incipit: Quis expediuit cythaco suum chere
msItem.note: Persius, 29 lines, Satyrae, 0.8

msItem.incipit: Crede mihi non est sapientis dicere
msItem.note: Martial, 14 lines, Epigrammata, 1. 15. 11

msItem.incipit: Non facile alterius repetas consortia dixit
msItem.note: Auianus, 22 lines, Fabulae, 9. 23

msItem.incipit: Amarum in muliere sapit membrorum sarcinia
msItem.note: Joh. de Hauvilla, Architrenius, 574 lines of which the first are 2.6–7, ed. P. G. Schmidt (Munich, 1974)

msItem.incipit: Probitas laudatur et alget
msItem.note: Juvenal, 40 lines, beg. with Satyrae, 1. 74

msItem.incipit: Segnius irritant animum demissa per aurem
msItem.note: Horace, 9 lines, beg. with Ars poetica, 180
Between (g) and (h) are further short excerpts from Ovid, Fasti and Metamorphoses, Virgil, Bucolics and Georgics. The heading, ‘Prouerbia poetharum’ on fol. 187v is added in Grandisson’s hand.

rubric.add: De spiritu et anima Hugo de sancto Victore

msItem.incipit: Interior substancia q’ constituit hominem
msItem.explicit: habet ponendi animam meam. dicit in sequentibus.
msItem.note: Unidentified. Not an excerpt from Alcherus (Ps.-Augustine) De spiritu et anima, pr. PL, 40.77–843, nor the text by Costa ben Luca ed. C. S. Bacharach, Excerptae libro Alfredi Anglici ... seu Costa-ben-Lucae De differentia animae et spiritu (Innsbruck, 1878), 120–39, nor Ps.-Hugo de S. Victore, De unione spiritus et animae, as in Oxford, Merton College, MS 49 fols. 90–92r. Chapters include ‘De anima et spiritu’, ‘De spiritu et mente’, ‘Quomodo anima dicitur fieri in spiritu’, ‘De memoria’, ‘Quomodo diliges dominum ex toto’, ‘Quomodo homo sit animalis et carnalis’. This item is in a later hand than the others although still written above the top line, and added in s. xv to the contents list on fol. iiv. At the top of fol. 198r is ‘xiijs et iiijd’. Fol. 198v is blank except for ‘reuelat brigide’ ‘d conquestie’ and ‘prec. xvi s.’, all s. xiv/xv. On the prices see below, History.

supportDesc.extent:
198 leaves preceded by one post-medieval paper flyleaf and one medieval membrane flyleaf, and followed by one post-medieval paper flyleaf. 323 220
245 70
Parchment of inferior quality. Fols. 184–6 are badly stained by a brown liquid.
supportDesc.collation: 1–612 712 (wants 6) 8–1612 178 (wants 8, blank). Catchwords, some trimmed. The only quire numbers are in pencil, supplied by the late 18th-century binder.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, 45 lines. Pricked in outer margins; ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Protogothic bookhand barely turning into gothic, by a number of scribes. All the scribes write above top line. Punctuation by low point and punctus versus. At the foot of fol. 159v, is ‘.xx. qtas’: as that leaf is the fourth leaf of the quire 14 and writing continues in the same hand to the end of the quire, it is unlikely to be the scribe’s calculation of work done but may refer to the stage he had reached in his exemplar.

decoDesc.decoNote: 1/5-line plain red and green initials. Rubrics; red paraphs and stroking of letters; lemmata underlined red.

binding.p: Sewn on five bands. Standard Exeter binding: simple and quite elegant, calf over millboards, the calf bearing blind decoration of a floral type, early 19th century. At the foot of fols. 198 back to 196 are stains which are probably from a chain clasp on an earlier binding.

history.provenance: At the top right-hand corner of fol. 1r is ‘Liber J. Exon’, in the distinctive hand of John Grandisson, bp. of Exeter 1327–69, in which there are also added titles before items 7, 8, 12, and 13. On him see BRUO.

On fol. 1r, in the hand that wrote the same inscription in MS 43, is ‘Hunc librum dedit magister Thomas Plymyswode Collegio seu Aule de Stapyldonhalle Oxon’ ad chathenandum in libraria ibidem. Oretis pro eo.’ The Rector’s Accounts for 1417/18 record two payments for the carriage of ‘libros legatos’ to the College and a third payment for binding MS 43, the other identified survivor. Plymyswode was a fellow of Exeter College in 1384, inter alia rector of Heavitree, now part of the city of Exeter, in 1396, and d. 1418 (BRUO). Judging by the date of the hand, prices on fols. 198r (xiijs. iiijd.) and 198v (xvjs.) may relate to his ownership.
Recorded at Exeter c. 1600 as Ecloga, no. 3, then in CMA, no. 38.
Exeter library identifications are: on the front pastedown, ‘Ex: Coll: Oxon:’, ‘Q, 8–3 Gall’ (deleted), ‘172.G.3.’, ‘Coxe Cat. no. xxiii’ and the book stamp.

source.bibl: Andrew G. Watson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Exeter College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press), 2000.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Exeter College Library.
